how_to_use.use_case_en:
• The Clinical Frailty Scale (CFS) is a simple instrument that can be used by almost anyone to quantify degree of frailty, which is often difficult to define. 

  • The CFS correlates reasonably well with medium and long term outcomes (measured in years) of patients in terms of both mortality and need for institutional care.
how_to_use.why_use_en: There are many frailty criteria, scores, and indices which can be lengthy and laborious to complete. The CFS has become used widely, likely due to its simplicity.

next_steps.advice_en: Do you use the CSHA Clinical Frailty Scale (CFS) and want to contribute your expertise? Join our contributor team!

creator_info.about_en: Kenneth Rockwood, MD, MPA, FRCPC, is a professor of medicine at Dalhousie University in Nova Scotia, Canada. He is also an investigator at the Canadian Institutes of Health Research and the Kathryn Allen Weldon Professor of Alzheimer Research at Dalhousie. Dr. Rockwood’s primary research is focused on the complexity and clinical and epidemiological aspects of frailty, dementia, and delirium.

expert_name.description: Graham Walker, MD, is an emergency physician practicing in San Francisco, California. Dr. Walker attended medical school at the Stanford University School of Medicine and then trained in emergency medicine at St. Luke’s-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York City, where he was Chief Resident. He returned to the west coast as a Medical Simulation fellow and attending in Stanford’s emergency department. More relevant, of course, is that Dr. Walker is the creator and developer of MDCalc and remains active in content and calculator development, along with our many other endeavors as President of MD Aware, LLC (MDCalc’s parent company).
